metadata.titleEn: Tree-ring width sequence and tree-ring chronology in Kaiken River Basin, Xinjiang
metadata.description:
This dataset includes 3 tree-ring width sequences and 1 tree-ring chronology in Kaiken River Basin, Xinjiang. Based on tree-ring cores collected from three sampling
sites in Kaiken River basin near Tien Shan, a regional tree-ring width chronology were developed. The correlation analysis showed that the runoff of Kaiken River from previous August to current June was significantly correlated with the regional chronology, and the high correlation coefficient was 0.661 (p < 0.01). Based on the regional chronology, the August-June runoff of Kaiken River has been reconstructed over the past 422 year, and it accounted for 43.7% of actual runoff variance during
the common period 1983–2013. The reconstruction model is reliable, and the trend of observed and reconstructed data is relatively consistent. The results of multi-taper spectral analysis for the runoff reconstruction indicated some remarkable cycles for the past 422 years; the 11.5-year cycles correspond to the solar cycle and is found widely in runoff reconstructions in Central Asia. This may imply a solar influence on the hydroclimate variations of Tien Shan. The runoff reconstruction of Kaiken River compares well with runoff reconstructions the Urumqi River and Manas River, and implies that there is a common driving factor for the runoff in central Tien Shan, China.
metadata.instructions: Chen et al-2020-Tree-ring width sequence and tree-ring chronology

literatureList.titleEn: A 422-year reconstruction of the Kaiken River streamflow, Xinjiang, Northwest China

background: Economic development, as well as urbanization and the increasing population, raises doubts over the supply of water resources to meet the growing needs of society in semiarid and arid areas around the world. However, instrumental hydrological records over Central Asia are short and sparse in spatial distribution, especially in Tien Shan, China. High-resolution hydrology proxy records, such as history records and tree rings, are needed to interpret the Central Asian hydrological changes. The Kaiken River basin is located in the northern slope of Tien Shan, Central Asia. During the historical period, the Kaiken River is always the most important water source for irrigation for the Qitai Oasis agriculture, and until 2004, the irrigation water still accounted for more than 97.6% of the utilization of water resources, which affected agricultural and animal husbandry production in Qitai. At the same time, the Kaiken River and the neighboring Manas and Urumqi rivers are the main sources of fresh water for the Central Asian largest urban agglomeration, included Shihezi and Urumqi. Tree rings are playing an increasingly vital role in revealing past climatic and environmental change. Nevertheless, runoff reconstructions are still insufficient in the vast areas of Central Asia for interpreting the recent hydrological variability in a long-term perspective.
research objective: In this research, we developed a new regional tree-ring width chronology of Picea schrenkiana from the Kaiken River basin, central Tien Shan, China. Based on tree-ring width data, we developed August–June runoff reconstruction for Kaiken River over the period 1592–2013 CE. This new runoff record is compared with existing runoff reconstructions from other parts of central Tien Shan.
challenges: Although the runoff reconstructions are preliminary, our reconstruction provides new insights into runoff variations in Tien Shan, Central Asia. More dendrohydrological studies will be needed to enable us to better understand problems such as the forcings responsible for Central Asian runoff variability and re-evaluation of water resources management, and so on.
methods: Tree-ring samples were chosen from three different sites in central Tien Shan in August 2008 and July 2014. Two cores per tree were obtained from the relatively old spruce trees at breast height. After dried, mounted on wooden holders, and polished with 400 grit sandpaper to enhance tree-ring bound, annual ring widths of all cores were measured by a manual Henson micrometer (LINTAB™, Rinntech, Heidelberg, Germany) with a 0.01 mm precision. The computer program COFECHA was applied to check cross-dated results of tree-ring series. The regional tree-ring width chronology (STD) were developed by the software ARSTAN. Each individual ring-width series was detrended by fitting a negative exponential curve.
findings: Based on the regional chronology, the August-June runoff of Kaiken River has been reconstructed over the past 422 years, and it accounted for 43.7% of actual runoff variance during the common period 1983–2013. The reconstruction model is reliable, and the trend of observed and reconstructed data is relatively consistent. The results of multi-taper spectral analysis for the runoff reconstruction indicated some remarkable cycles for the past 422 years; the 11.5-year cycles correspond to the solar cycle and is found widely in runoff reconstructions in Central Asia. This may imply a solar influence on the hydroclimate variations of Tien Shan. The runoff reconstruction of Kaiken River compares well with runoff reconstructions of the Urumqi River and Manas River, and implies that there is a common driving factor for the runoff in central Tien Shan, China. Our 422-year streamflow reconstruction provides long-term perspective on current and 20th century hydrological events in central Tien Shan, is useful for aids sustainable water management and addresses regional climate change challenges.

Verification.Question: Are tree-ring samples from multiple sites utilized in data collection for dendrohydrological studies in the Kaiken River Basin?
Is the COFECHA program used for checking cross-dated results in tree-ring series?
Does the method of using tree-ring width data in this field help reconstruct historical runoff records?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary data collection method for tree-ring data in the Kaiken River Basin based on manual measurement using devices like the Henson micrometer, automated systems, or satellite imagery?
Disjunctive.Answer: manual measurement using devices like the Henson micrometer

Disjunctive.Question: Does the tree-ring width dataset from the Kaiken River Basin primarily contribute to understanding solar influence on hydroclimate variations, identifying regional water management strategies, or assessing agricultural irrigation needs?
Disjunctive.Answer: understanding solar influence on hydroclimate variations

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges associated with runoff reconstructions in the Kaiken River Basin?
Concept Completion.Answer: understanding the forcings responsible for Central Asian runoff variability

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the regional tree-ring width chronology developed for the Kaiken River Basin?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain tree-ring width measurements for hydrological reconstructions?
Example.Answer: Tree-ring samples were chosen from three different sites in central Tien Shan in August 2008 and July 2014. Two cores per tree were obtained from the relatively old spruce trees at breast height. After dried, mounted on wooden holders, and polished with 400 grit sandpaper to enhance tree-ring bound, annual ring widths of all cores were measured by a manual Henson micrometer (LINTAB™, Rinntech, Heidelberg, Germany) with a 0.01 mm precision.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge faced when using tree-ring data for runoff reconstructions in Central Asia?
Example.Answer: Although the runoff reconstructions are preliminary, the challenge includes the need for more dendrohydrological studies to enable a better understanding of the forcings responsible for Central Asian runoff variability and re-evaluation of water resources management.

Example.Question: What is an example of a finding from using tree-ring width chronology for runoff reconstruction in the Kaiken River basin?
Example.Answer: Based on the regional chronology, the August-June runoff of Kaiken River has been reconstructed over the past 422 years, and it accounted for 43.7% of actual runoff variance during the common period 1983–2013. The results of multi-taper spectral analysis for the runoff reconstruction indicated some remarkable cycles for the past 422 years; the 11.5-year cycles correspond to the solar cycle and is found widely in runoff reconstructions in Central Asia.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with using tree-ring data for hydrological reconstructions in Central Asia, and how can these be addressed?
Feature Specification.Answer: preliminary nature of runoff reconstructions, need for more dendrohydrological studies

Quantification.Question: What is the timeframe covered by the runoff reconstruction for the Kaiken River?
To what degree does the reconstructed August-June runoff of the Kaiken River account for actual runoff variance during a specified period?

Definition.Question: What is 'detrending' in the context of tree-ring data analysis?
Definition.Answer: 'Detrending' in tree-ring data analysis involves removing non-climatic influences on tree growth, such as age-related growth trends or other biological factors, by fitting a curve (e.g., a negative exponential curve) to the data. This process isolates the climatic signals embedded in the tree-ring widths, allowing for more accurate reconstructions of past environmental conditions.

Definition.Question: What does 'multitaper spectral analysis' mean in the context of runoff reconstructions?
Definition.Answer: 'Multitaper spectral analysis' in runoff reconstructions is a method used to identify periodicities and cycles in historical runoff data. This technique allows researchers to detect significant cycles, such as the 11.5-year solar cycle, by analyzing the variability in reconstructed runoff records over extended periods, providing insights into potential climatic influences on hydrological changes.

Interpretation.Question: What patterns or cycles can be interpreted from the dendrochronological data of tree rings in relation to Central Asian hydrological changes?
Interpretation.Answer: The dendrochronological data reveal significant cycles over the past 422 years, such as the 11.5-year cycles that correspond to the solar cycle. These patterns suggest that solar influence might affect the hydroclimate variations of Tien Shan.

Interpretation.Question: How can the challenges of sparse and short instrumental hydrological records in Central Asia be addressed through alternative data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: High-resolution hydrology proxy records, such as tree rings, provide valuable data to interpret Central Asian hydrological changes, offering insights that overcome the limitations of sparse and short instrumental records.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying factors might contribute to the consistency observed between the reconstructed runoff data and actual runoff variance in the Kaiken River region?
Interpretation.Answer: The reconstructed runoff data account for 43.7% of actual runoff variance during the common period 1983–2013, indicating reliable modeling and consistent trends between observed and reconstructed data. This consistency implies a common driving factor for runoff in central Tien Shan, such as solar influence, which is observed in similar reconstructions of neighboring river systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the selection of tree-ring samples in the data collection process for hydrological reconstructions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Tree-ring samples were chosen from three different sites in central Tien Shan, with selections made from relatively old spruce trees to ensure accurate and relevant data for the hydrological reconstructions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the common driving factors in runoff reconstructions across different rivers in central Tien Shan?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The common driving factors in runoff reconstructions, as observed in the Kaiken River and its comparison with the Urumqi River and Manas River, may imply a solar influence on the hydroclimate variations, suggesting a shared climatic or environmental influence affecting runoff in central Tien Shan.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the reliability of runoff reconstructions when using tree-ring width data from multiple sites in central Tien Shan?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using tree-ring width data from multiple sites in central Tien Shan allows for a more comprehensive understanding of runoff variability, providing new insights into runoff variations and increasing the reliability of the reconstruction models for the Kaiken River basin.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the application of software like COFECHA and ARSTAN affect the accuracy and consistency of cross-dated tree-ring series in hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of software such as COFECHA and ARSTAN enhances the accuracy and consistency of cross-dated tree-ring series by ensuring precise measurements and developing reliable regional tree-ring width chronologies, which are crucial for accurate runoff reconstructions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for water resource management in Central Asia if tree-ring width chronologies indicate a common driving factor for runoff variability in the region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: If tree-ring width chronologies indicate a common driving factor for runoff variability, it could lead to more informed water resource management strategies in Central Asia, enabling better planning and adaptation to hydrological changes influenced by regional climate factors.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to reconstruct the runoff of the Kaiken River over the past 422 years using tree-ring width data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Reconstructing the runoff is important to provide insights into runoff variations in Tien Shan, Central Asia, and to offer a long-term perspective on current and 20th-century hydrological events. It aids in sustainable water management and addresses regional climate change challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of comparing the new runoff record with existing runoff reconstructions from other parts of central Tien Shan?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include understanding the common driving factors for runoff in central Tien Shan, China, and identifying patterns such as the 11.5-year solar cycle that widely affects runoff reconstructions in Central Asia. This comparison helps in re-evaluating water resources management and understanding the forcings responsible for Central Asian runoff variability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are followed in collecting and processing tree-ring width data for historical runoff reconstruction in Central Asia?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Tree-ring samples are collected from three different sites in central Tien Shan. Two cores per tree are obtained from relatively old spruce trees at breast height. After drying, mounting on wooden holders, and polishing with sandpaper, annual ring widths of all cores are measured using a manual Henson micrometer with 0.01 mm precision. Cross-dating of tree-ring series is checked with the COFECHA program, and the regional tree-ring width chronology is developed using ARSTAN software. Individual ring-width series are detrended by fitting a negative exponential curve.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the tree-ring width chronology used to reconstruct past runoff in the Kaiken River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Based on the regional tree-ring width chronology, the August-June runoff of Kaiken River is reconstructed for the past 422 years. The reconstruction model accounts for 43.7% of actual runoff variance during the common period 1983–2013, indicating reliability. The comparison of observed and reconstructed data trends shows consistency, enabling long-term perspectives on hydrological events.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges faced in developing a reliable runoff reconstruction model using tree-ring data in the Central Asian context?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the preliminary nature of runoff reconstructions and the need for more dendrohydrological studies to understand forcings responsible for runoff variability in Central Asia. The sparse spatial distribution of instrumental hydrological records in Central Asia, especially in Tien Shan, necessitates high-resolution proxy records to interpret long-term hydrological changes.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the precise measurement of tree-ring widths in dendrohydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a manual Henson micrometer (LINTAB™) with a precision of 0.01 mm, along with computer programs like COFECHA for checking cross-dated results, enables precise measurement of tree-ring widths.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of software tools enhance the development of a regional tree-ring width chronology for hydrological reconstructions?
Enablement.Answer: Software like ARSTAN is used to develop regional tree-ring width chronologies by detrending individual ring-width series with negative exponential curves, which enhances the accuracy and reliability of hydrological reconstructions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methods are necessary to ensure the reliability of runoff reconstruction models in historical hydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: Ensuring the reliability of runoff reconstruction models involves using high-resolution proxy records like tree rings, applying robust statistical models, and comparing reconstructed data with observed data to ensure consistency in trends.

Expectation.Question: Why might tree-ring width chronologies be expected to provide reliable insights into historical runoff variability in arid and semiarid regions like Central Asia?
Expectation.Answer: Tree rings are high-resolution hydrology proxy records that can reveal past climatic and environmental changes. In the context of Central Asia, where instrumental hydrological records are short and sparse, tree-ring width chronologies offer a valuable means to interpret hydrological changes over long periods.

Expectation.Question: What are some expected challenges in developing a reliable runoff reconstruction model using tree-ring data in regions like the Tien Shan?
Expectation.Answer: Developing a reliable runoff reconstruction model using tree-ring data can be challenging due to the preliminary nature of some reconstructions and the need for more dendrohydrological studies. These studies are essential to better understand the forcings responsible for Central Asian runoff variability and to re-evaluate water resources management.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be expected that tree-ring based runoff reconstructions from different rivers in the Tien Shan region show similar patterns or driving factors?
Expectation.Answer: Tree-ring based runoff reconstructions from different rivers in the Tien Shan region might show similar patterns or driving factors because the runoff reconstruction of the Kaiken River compares well with the Urumqi and Manas rivers. This implies that there is a common driving factor for runoff in central Tien Shan, which could be influenced by solar cycles as indicated by the presence of an 11.5-year cycle found widely in the region's runoff reconstructions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits of expanding dendrochronological datasets for understanding water resource management in Central Asia?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding dendrochronological datasets can provide a long-term perspective on hydrological events, aiding in sustainable water management and addressing regional climate change challenges. By offering insights into past runoff variability and its driving factors, these datasets can help evaluate and improve current water resource management strategies.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how tree-ring data can be used effectively to reconstruct historical runoff in river basins.
Assertion.Answer: Tree-ring samples, specifically from Picea schrenkiana in the Kaiken River basin, are collected and analyzed to develop a tree-ring width chronology. This data is then used to reconstruct historical runoff by comparing it with existing runoff reconstructions and applying models that account for past hydrological changes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when developing a regional tree-ring chronology for hydrological studies.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include ensuring accurate cross-dating of tree-ring series, dealing with preliminary runoff reconstructions, and understanding the forcings responsible for runoff variability. More dendrohydrological studies are needed for better insights into these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how solar cycles are related to hydrological changes observed in tree-ring data.
Assertion.Answer: The multi-taper spectral analysis of the runoff reconstruction indicated that an 11.5-year cycle, corresponding to the solar cycle, is present in the tree-ring data. This suggests a potential solar influence on the hydroclimate variations in the Tien Shan region.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for gathering tree-ring width data in the Kaiken River Basin and suggest improvements for enhancing accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Tree-ring samples were collected from three different sites in central Tien Shan. Two cores per tree were obtained from old spruce trees at breast height. The samples were dried, mounted, and polished for ring boundary enhancement. Ring widths were measured using a manual Henson micrometer with 0.01 mm precision. COFECHA was used for cross-dating, and ARSTAN software was used to develop the regional tree-ring width chronology. Improvements could involve using advanced imaging techniques for more precise ring measurement and incorporating additional climate proxies for cross-validation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in the dendrohydrological studies of the Kaiken River Basin and propose strategies to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the preliminary nature of the runoff reconstructions and the need for more dendrohydrological studies to understand the forcings behind runoff variability. To address these challenges, further studies could incorporate multiple tree species to improve robustness, utilize longer instrumental records for calibration, and apply advanced statistical models to identify external climatic influences.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding datasets related to tree-ring width and runoff reconstructions in the Kaiken River Basin.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding datasets could involve collecting additional tree-ring samples from a wider range of sites across the Tien Shan to increase spatial coverage. Integrating other proxy data like pollen analysis and lake sediments could provide complementary insights. Collaborations with regional hydrological monitoring programs could offer newer runoff measurements to refine existing reconstructions.
